NATO faces logistics challenge over moving tanks across EU in face of Russian threat
subhead: Long overlooked, the question of military mobility has returned to the forefront of Western priorities in response to the Russian threat. Amid delayed investments, bureaucratic hurdles and continued dependence on the United States, Europeans have been striving to build infrastructure capable of supporting the rapid deployment of alliance troops to the eastern flank.

subhead: The history of the Czech Republic and Slovenia only partly explains the starkly contrasting stances these two countries take on Israel today, writes historian Jean-Pierre Filiu in his column for Le Monde.

title: Sudanese refugees fleeing war find shelter under Paris bridge
subhead: In the north of the French capital, migrants have set up a makeshift camp. Many are from Darfur and fled a region torn by fighting between the Khartoum army and the Rapid Support Forces paramilitaries.

title: 'China. Prints of the past': The art of rubbing revealed at Paris's Musée Cernuschi
subhead: An exhibition brings together approximately 150 works that bear witness to a practice born in ancient China to preserve imprints of relics from the past.

title: How the French left fractured over security and secularism after 2015 Paris attacks
subhead: Then president François Hollande's proposal to enshrine the revocation of citizenship in the Constitution after the attacks deeply divided his own political camp, just as debates over secularism and Islam became flashpoints.

subhead: From the 2024 Olympic Games to the bustling café terraces, the city has found countless ways to make love outshine death.

title: COP30: 'Those drawn to China's environmental push should keep a few facts in mind'
subhead: China is presenting itself as the leader in the renewable energy economy, positioning itself against the United States, which remains entrenched in fossil fuels. Yet, this transition has proven misleading, writes Pascal Riché in his column for Le Monde.

title: Sudan: Humanitarian crisis from Darfur war spills over into Chad
subhead: For more than 20 years, N'Djamena has endured the consequences of the Sudanese conflict, hosting over one million refugees. Chad has also acted as a backer of armed groups when it suits its interests, risking internal destabilization.
